battleships package

Submodules

battleships.advanced_ai module

This module just deals with the AI when its doing more advanced

attacking rather than random guesses

battleships.advanced_ai.generate_advanced_attack(difficulty: int, enemy_dict: dict, history: list) → tuple[int, int][source]

Generates more advanced attack position than the attack function in the specification

Parameters:

  • difficulty – 0 (easy) -> 4 (intelligent)

  • enemy_dict – So we can get the enemy’s board and original board

  • history – Our move history, so we know where we have already guessed

Returns:

A location on the board as a tuple

battleships.advanced_ai.generate_attack_difficulty_0(board_size: int) → tuple[int, int][source]

Purely random attacking method (what’s defined in the spec)

Parameters:

board_size – Size of the board

Returns:

attack coordinate

battleships.advanced_ai.generate_attack_difficulty_1(board_size: int, history: list[tuple[int, int]]) → tuple[int, int][source]

Semi random guess - ie its random but it won’t guess the same place twice

Parameters:

  • board_size – Size of board

  • history – list of where has been guessed before

Returns:

The guess

battleships.advanced_ai.generate_attack_difficulty_2(enemy_dict: dict, history: list[tuple[int, int]]) → tuple[int, int][source]

This does semi intelligent guessing around unsunk hits (it chooses a random location adjacent to unsunk hits) if no unsunk hits it guesses randomly

Parameters:

  • enemy_dict – So we can get the enemy’s board and original board

  • history – list of where has been guessed before

Returns:

The guess

battleships.advanced_ai.generate_attack_difficulty_3(enemy_dict: dict, history: list[tuple[int, int]]) → tuple[int, int][source]

A bit better than difficulty 2, this tries to follow lines in the unsunk hits Still does random guessing if it can’t find any unsunk hits

Parameters:

  • enemy_dict – So we can get the enemy’s board and original board

  • history – list of where has been guessed before

Returns:

The guess location

battleships.advanced_ai.generate_attack_difficulty_4(enemy_dict: dict, history: list[tuple[int, int]]) → tuple[int, int][source]

If it has unsunk hits then it does the same as difficulty 3 But if no unsunk hits found then it does more intelligent random guessing

Parameters:

  • enemy_dict – So we can get the enemy’s board and original board

  • history – list of where has been guessed before

Returns:

The guess location

battleships.advanced_ai.generate_intelligent_blind_guess(enemy_dict, history)[source]

When there are no unsunk ships to guess around this algorithm gives the best place to try and look for a ship

Parameters:

  • enemy_dict – So we can get the enemy’s board and original board

  • history – list of where has been guessed before

Returns:

A location to guess

battleships.advanced_ai.get_surrounding_tiles(search_tiles: list[tuple[int, int]], board_size: int) → list[tuple[int, int]][source]

Gives a list of the tiles surrounding the tiles given by ‘search_tiles’ parameter primarily used for finding tiles around unsunk hits

Parameters:

  • search_tiles – The tiles to look around

  • board_size – The size of the board

Returns:

The list of surrounding tiles

battleships.advanced_ai.get_unsunk_hits(enemy_dict: dict) → list[tuple[int, int]][source]

Find all the cells in the board that have been hit but not sunk

Parameters:

enemy_dict – So we can get the enemy’s board and original board

Returns:

The list of unsunk hit locations

battleships.advanced_ai.guess_line_attack(enemy_dict: dict, history: list[tuple[int, int]]) → tuple[int, int][source]

Generates a guess based on following lines in the unsunk hits to try and find ships

Parameters:

  • enemy_dict – So we can get the enemy’s board and original board

  • history – Our move history, so we know where we have already guessed

Returns:

A guess following a line if possible

battleships.ai_comparison module

This script is for comparing different difficulties of AI over many games

battleships.ai_comparison.ai_loop(ai_mode_1: int, ai_mode_2: int) → tuple[str, int][source]

Runs a single game between two AIs

Parameters:

  • ai_mode_1 – the difficulty of AI 1

  • ai_mode_2 – the difficulty of AI 2

Returns:

‘AI1’ if AI1 won or ‘AI2’ if AI2 won

battleships.ai_comparison.run_trials(ai1_mode: int, ai2_mode: int, trials: int = 1000) → None[source]

Runs a number of games against the AI and prints the result

Parameters:

  • ai1_mode – the difficulty of AI 1

  • ai2_mode – the difficulty of AI 2

  • trials – How many trials to run

Returns:

None

battleships.components module

Basic functions used mainly for setting up games

battleships.components.create_battleships(filename: str = 'battleships.txt') → dict[str, int][source]

This function extracts the battleship data from a file

Parameters:

filename – The file to read ship data from

Returns:

A dictionary with the ships’ names and sizes

battleships.components.get_positions_by_name(board: list[list], names: list[str]) → list[tuple[int, int]][source]

Returns a list of all the tuple positions on the board that are occupied by a ship with name in list names. Primarily used for finding sunk ships

Parameters:

  • board – The board to search in

  • names – The names of the ships to look for

Returns:

A list of the positions with name in list ‘names’

battleships.components.get_sunken_ships(player_data: dict) → list[tuple[int, int]][source]

Calculate which of a player’s ships we have sunk based on its original board

Parameters:

player_data – The dict containing boards, ships etc.

Returns:

A list of positions that have been sunk

battleships.components.in_board(location: tuple[int, int], board: list[list]) → bool[source]

Returns whether a point is inside the board or not

Parameters:

  • location – The point to query

  • board – Reference to the board so we can find it’s size

Returns:

Whether its inside

battleships.components.initialise_board(size: int = 10) → list[list][source]

Creates a blank board of size ‘size’

Parameters:

size – How big the board should be in both x and y directions

Returns:

An empty list of lists (filled with None values)

battleships.components.place_battleships(board: list[list], ships: dict[str, int], algorithm: str = 'simple', use_absolute_path: bool = True) → list[list[str]][source]

Places all the ships onto the board using a specified placement algorithm

Parameters:

  • board – A list of lists representing the board

  • ships – A dictionary of ships in the game and their sizes

  • algorithm – either ‘simple’, ‘random’ or ‘custom’

  • use_absolute_path – Should it use a relative or absolute path (for pytest)

Returns:

A list of lists representing the board, with tiles filled where ships are

battleships.components.place_battleships_custom(board: list[list], ships: dict[str, int], use_absolute_path: bool = True) → list[list[str]][source]

Places all the ships onto the board using a custom placement algorithm

Parameters:

  • board – A list of lists representing the board

  • ships – A dictionary of ships in the game and their sizes

  • use_absolute_path – Should it use a relative or absolute path (for pytest)

Returns:

A list of lists representing the board, with tiles filled where ships are

battleships.components.place_battleships_random(board: list[list], ships: dict[str, int]) → list[list[str]][source]

Places all the ships onto the board using a random placement

Parameters:

  • board – A list of lists representing the board

  • ships – A dictionary of ships in the game and their sizes

Returns:

A list of lists representing the board, with tiles filled where ships are

battleships.components.try_place_ship(board: list[list], ship_name: str, ship_size: int, position: tuple[int, int], orientation: str) → list[list[str | None]] | None[source]

Used for the random placement method in place_battleships function

Parameters:

  • board – A list of lists representing the board

  • ship_name – The name of the ship being placed

  • ship_size – The size of the ship being placed

  • position – starting position of the ship

  • orientation – what direction the ship faces ‘v’ = down, ‘h’ = right

Returns:

None if the placement is invalid, else the updated board list of lists

battleships.game_engine module

Functions used in gameplay Also contains a single-player game if module is executed

battleships.game_engine.attack(coordinates: tuple[int, int], board: list[list[str | None]], battleships: dict[str, int]) → bool[source]

This function returns whether there is a ship hit when you fire at a location

Parameters:

  • coordinates – Coordinates to check if there’s a ship

  • board – The board (list of lists) to check

  • battleships – The list of enemy ships to decrement if there’s a hit

Returns:

Bool Whether anything was hit

battleships.game_engine.cli_coordinates_input() → tuple[int, int][source]

Requests the user for input coordinates then returns the tuple position

Returns:

returns the tuple position of inputted coordinates

battleships.game_engine.count_ships_remaining(ships: dict[str, int]) → int[source]

Counts how many un-sunk tiles there are left

Parameters:

ships – The dictionary of a player’s ships

Returns:

the number of ship tiles left

battleships.game_engine.simple_game_loop() → None[source]

Plays a single player game in the command line

Returns:

None

battleships.main module

This module runs the main battleships game

class battleships.main.BattleshipsGame[source]

Bases: object

Encapsulated the battleships game functions into a class so we don’t need to use global variables

entry_interface() → dict | None[source]

When the Start game button gets pressed on the entry interface this gets triggered It sets up a game with the data returned

Returns:

dictionary to show it was received OK

handle_menu() → dict | None[source]

When the return to menu button gets pressed this gets triggered. Just stops the game and will return to the entry screen

Returns:

A dict just to show it completed fine

placement_interface() → str[source]

This handles the placement menu, so when you first put your ships on the board

Returns:

Returns a JSON file if it’s a POST request, or the HTML webpage if it’s not

process_attack() → dict[source]

This handles When a user sends an attack

Returns:

The status of the user’s attack and where the AI fired back

root() → str[source]

Handles the main gameplay webpage, if game isn’t set up then it goes to the placement page

Returns:

HTML web pages: either placement if the board needs to be set up or gameplay if it has already

battleships.main.entry_interface() → dict[source]

Returns the game instance’s entry_interface function result

Returns:

The dictionary result to respond that the entry_interface function worked

battleships.main.handle_menu() → dict[source]

Returns the game instance’s handle_menu function result

Returns:

The dictionary result to respond that the handle_menu function worked

battleships.main.placement_interface() → str[source]

returns the game instance’s placement_interface function

Returns:

Returns a JSON file if it’s a POST request, or the HTML webpage if it’s not

battleships.main.process_attack() → dict[source]

returns the game instance’s handle_attack function

Returns:

The status of the user’s attack and where the AI fired back

battleships.main.root() → str[source]

returns the game instance’s root function

Returns:

HTML web pages: either placement if the board needs to be set up

or gameplay if it has already

battleships.mp_game_engine module

Contains functions needed for a multiplayer game, ie generating attacks etc. Also contains a simple Command line game when module itself is executed

battleships.mp_game_engine.ai_opponent_game_loop() → None[source]

Plays a command line game of battleships against an AI

Returns:

None

battleships.mp_game_engine.display_ascii(board: list[list[str | None]]) → None[source]

Displays a given board on the command line

Parameters:

board – The board to display

Returns:

None, it prints the result

battleships.mp_game_engine.generate_attack(board: list[list[str | None]] = None) → tuple[int, int][source]

Generates a position to attack via specification random method

Parameters:

board – input the board to attack so the algorithm knows how large it is. Unittests assume

there are no arguments for generate_attack so if we get not argument assume board_size = 10 :return: a tuple coordinate on the grid
